description:
The '''Canterbury scene''' (or '''Canterbury sound''') is a musical scene that originated in the city of [[Canterbury]], [[Kent]], England during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Associated with [[progressive rock]], the term describes a loosely-defined, [[improvisation]]al style that blended elements of [[jazz]], [[rock music|rock]], and [[psychedelic music|psychedelia]].

These musicians played together in numerous bands, with ever-changing and overlapping personnel, creating some similarities in their musical output.  Many prominent British [[Avant-garde jazz|avant-garde]] or [[Jazz fusion|fusion]] musicians began their career in Canterbury bands, including [[Hugh Hopper]], [[Steve Hillage]], [[Dave Stewart (musician, born 1950)|Dave Stewart]], [[Robert Wyatt]], [[Kevin Ayers]], [[Richard Sinclair]], [[Daevid Allen]], and [[Mike Ratledge]].
